{{Infobox person |name= John Morgan |image=John Morgan.gif |image_size= |caption= |birth_date= {{birth date|1930|9|21|mf=y}} |birth_place= [[Aberdare, Wales|Aberdare]], [[Wales]] |death_date= {{death date and age|2004|11|15|1930|9|21|mf=y}} |death_place= [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada }} '''John Morgan''' (September 21, 1930 – November 15, 2004) was a [[Wales|Welsh]]-born [[Canadians|Canadian]] comedian.
Born in [[Aberdare, Wales|Aberdare]], [[Wales]], Morgan played numerous characters on the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] [[sketch comedy]] [[television program|television series]] ''[[Royal Canadian Air Farce]]'' from 1993 to 2001 and its predecessor on [[CBC Radio]], including perpetually disgusted [[Scotland|Scotsman]] Jock McBile, socialite Amy De La Pompa, and monosyllabic [[Mike, from Canmore|Mike from]] [[Canmore, Alberta|Canmore]], as well as [[satire|satirical]] portrayals of such prominent individuals as [[Herb Gray]], [[Deborah Grey]], and [[Boris Yeltsin]]. He was a co-founder of the series, and critics called him its heart.
Morgan wrote the [[television pilot|pilot]] for the popular Canadian [[situation comedy|sitcom]], ''[[King of Kensington]]''. He and writing partner [[Martin Bronstein]] were also co-creators of the CBC radio series, ''Funny You Should Say That''. He had his own [[BBC Radio]] series called ''[[It's All in the Mind of John Morgan]]''.
In 2000, he was nominated for a [[Canadian Comedy Award]]. Along with the original cast of [[Air Farce Live|Air Farce]] – [[Roger Abbott]], [[Don Ferguson (actor)|Don Ferguson]] and [[Luba Goy]] – Morgan received the [[Governor General's Performing Arts Award]] for Lifetime Artistic Achievement in 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ggpaa.ca/award-recipients/1998/the-royal-canadian-air-farce-(roger-abbott-1946-20.aspx|publisher=Governor General's Performing Arts Awards Foundation|accessdate=4 February 2015}}</ref>
Before launching his comedy career in 1966, Morgan worked as a [[journalist]], [[editing|editor]], [[teacher]], and [[pub]] owner.
On November 15, 2004, Morgan died at his home in [[Toronto]] from a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at the age of 74.
